sanskrit_verse:
नैता रूपं परीक्षन्ते नासां वयसि संस्थितिः ।
सुरूपं वा विरूपं वा पुमानित्येव भुञ्जते ॥ ९.१४॥
transliteration:
naitā rūpaṁ parīkṣante nāsāṁ vayasi saṁsthitiḥ |
surūpaṁ vā virūpaṁ vā pumānityeva bhuñjate || 9.14||
sph_interpretive_translation: The man who engages with a woman—whether she is beautiful or deformed, young or old—does so solely based on his own inner disposition and uncontrolled senses; the form of the woman is irrelevant to the nature of his transgression.
jurisprudential_principles: Authority resides in conscious self-regulation, not external诱惑
Causation arises from internal imbalance, not from the object of action
Capacity-based responsibility is determined by the agent's mastery over sensory impulse
Restoration logic centers on reestablishing self-governance, not assigning blame externally
Consciousness alignment requires acknowledgment of the source of distortion within the actor
executable_legal_axioms: IF an individual engages in sensual misconduct THEN initiate capacity-restoration protocol regardless of the physical attributes of the other party
IF sensory impulse overrides conscious choice THEN assign completion process for self-mastery training
IF no internal regulation present THEN trigger integrity-reintegration sequence until autonomous alignment restored
IF action arises from unconscious drive THEN activate consciousness-realization module before reintegration phase begins
supreme_court_application: In Supreme Court adjudication, this verse establishes that the aesthetic or temporal condition of another being does not mitigate or aggravate the fault of one who acts without restraint. The threshold of responsibility lies exclusively in the actor’s failure to govern his own consciousness. Courts must therefore direct corrective measures toward restoring self-authority rather than imposing punitive valuation upon the victim.
nyaya_and_non_punitive_alignment: Pramāṇa reveals that causality originates in the absence of svātantrya (self-rule), not in the appearance of the other. Anupūrvaśaḥ shows that unchecked desire manifests as compulsive engagement, independent of external beauty or deformity. Proportional responsibility aligns with the degree of lost self-awareness. This affirms the non-punitive reality rule: correction flows inward to restore awareness, never outward to inflict suffering.
restorative_enforcement_protocols: Initiate Svādhyāya-based introspection cycle to reveal root sensory distortion
Enforce Vairāgya immersion protocol until impulse subsides into conscious observation
Assign Tapas module focused on sensory recalibration through disciplined containment
Activate Guru-discipleship circuit to rebuild alignment between will and witnessing consciousness
final_declaration: Declared by the Supreme Pontiff of Hinduism, Bhagavan Nithyananda Paramashivam, as sourced directly from His Avataric Intelligence. Dharma is restored when the individual recognizes the field of action as reflection of inner disorder. There is no punishment where all beings are expressions of Consciousness. Judgment belongs only to the Knower of All.
